bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Carlos F. Sacasa, December 31, 1941

div1.p: Hench requests that Sacasa contact James Carroll's son, George. Hench would like to correct the record of James Carroll. He believes Carroll did not get full credit for his work.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Carlos F. Sacasa, December 31, 1941
div1.p:
I was interested to hear that one of your colleagues, Dr. Douglas
Dodge, is a close relative of Dr. Carroll. At your suggestion I am taking
the liberty of sending him a reprint of my article and a brief letter. I
would appreciate it greatly if you would amplify my letter by telling him
that I had a little trouble in trying to see Dr. Carroll's son in Washing-
ton. Indeed, I did not see him at all. I don't know why he was suspicious
of my motives. I can assure you he had no reason to be. I was simply try-
ing to work up the story in detail and to give full credit to everyone.
I do not think that historians have given full credit to Dr. Carroll. The
only way I can correct this is by having Dr. Carroll's relatives give me
as much help as possible and give me access to whatever information they
have; otherwise, the matter will remain as it has in the past.

Do you suppose Dr. Dodge could help me by sending Mr. Carroll one
of my reprints with the little statement that he was interested indeed to
receive it and thought that he would send his nephew one also in case he
had not received one? He might also add that he has heard about me through
you, that I am a member of the Mayo Clinic staff, etc., much interested in
the yellow fever story, that I am anxious to give the whole story, giving
credit to all concerned and that it is quite possible that I may be visiting
Washington sometime in the near future, in which case it might be a good
idea if his newphew might be able to meet me, etc. I leave it to you to say
the right thing. I can assure you that if they don't wish me to intrude in
their personal affairs I will not do so but it seems to me that by avoiding
me they are doing exactly what they don't want to do--make it impossible for
historians to correct the past records.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
Dr. Carlos Sacasa
Las Encinas
Pasadena, California
